;;秦刚（左）和李尚福（右）当选后三月在北京。
;

;据官方媒体报道，中国已罢免国防部长李尚福，并将前外交部长秦刚赶出内阁，这是一次高层领导层的重大改组。

;

;这一消息是在对国家内阁进行了数月的猜测之后发布的，包括对秦七月在没有任何解释的情况下突然下台以及李鸿章几个月没有出现在公众视野中的困惑。

;

;秦和李都被相信国家主席习近平亲自挑选的专家担任职务。

;

;国家广播公司中央电视台在周二的晚间例行公报中宣布了这些部长的免职，但没有提供部长们失宠的原因

;

;没有宣布接替李担任国防部长。

;

;此前有报道称，美国政府认为李正在接受调查，并已被解除国防部长职务，但中国拒绝对此事发表评论。

;

;李先生于 8 月前往俄罗斯，参加 8 月 15 日在莫斯科附近举行的安全会议。两天后，白俄罗斯政府公布了李克强在明斯克会见白俄罗斯总统亚历山大·卢卡申科的传单照片。但此后他就从公众视野中消失了。

;

;李克强的被确认免职意味着下周中国的地区安全对话——香山论坛——将没有美国国务院代表参加的明显主办方专家表示，周二的声明加深了近期围绕中国最高领导层的不确定性。亚洲协会政策研究所中国政治研究员尼尔·托马斯表示，最近的剧变“暗示着去年的党的二十大上，高级官员的审查程序存在严重缺陷，可能是因为下级官员不想反对习近平所青睐的候选人”。

;

;但李和秦的免职是托马斯说，“不太可能严重削弱（习近平）的政治权威，因为他们都不属于他真正的核心圈子。”

;

;“他们的清洗向其他官员强调了保留习近平支持的重要性。”

; >;

;除了被免去国防部长职务外，李还失去了在国务院（中国内阁）的职位。

;

;秦刚在 207 年后被北京最高立法机构免去外交部长职务。任职数天后，现在也被剥夺了内阁职位。

;

;他的位置由王毅接替，王毅是一位资深外交官，在秦国之前曾担任外交部长，在中国政府层级中的地位高于他。< /p>;

;央视周二还宣布，免去科技部部长王志刚和财政部部长刘昆的职务。

;

;他们将由现任科技部接替。

;

;中国内参通讯出版人倪亚当表示，这些解雇事件表明“精英政治在起作用”。< /p>;

;“尽管习近平巩固了最高权力，但领导层的不稳定仍然有增无减，”他补充道，“除了极少数人之外，所有在习近平之下的人都会迅速失去权力”。

; < p>;“它们可以被采摘，也可以被丢弃，”倪说。

; Tue, 24 Oct 2023 23:52:01 +0800 ‘Catastrophic’: bird flu reaches Antarctic for the first timehttps://www.theguardian.com/environment/2023/oct/24/catastrophic-penguins-and-seals-at-risk-as-bird-flu-reaches-antarctic-aoe

;;南极洲库弗维尔岛上的棕色贼鸥和巴布亚企鹅。
;

;禽流感已抵达南极洲，引发了人们对以前从未接触过致命 H5N1 病毒的孤立企鹅和海豹种群的担忧。该病毒到来的全面影响尚不清楚，但科学家们对该地区脆弱的野生动物种群可能出现“灾难性繁殖失败”表示担忧。

;

;该病毒是在一种名为棕嘴雀的食腐鸟种群中发现的。伯德岛上的贼鸥，该岛是英国海外领土南乔治亚岛和南桑威奇群岛的一部分。这些候鸟可能从南美洲带来了病毒，那里禽流感很普遍，并且已经杀死了;估计;仅在智利和秘鲁就有 500,000 只海鸟和 20,000 只海狮。

;

;目前 H5N1 高度传染性变种的爆发（始于 2021 年）估计已导致杀死了数百万只野生鸟类。研究人员长期以来一直担心它对南极野生动物的潜在影响，因为许多物种在世界其他地方都没有发现，而且以前不知道是否接触过禽流感病毒。

;

;研究人员 ;来自英国南极调查局 (BAS);发现无法解释的死亡，并将其送往英国进行检测。

;

;伯德岛 BAS 科学经理阿什利·本尼森 (Ashley Bennison) 表示：“这是一个特别令人悲伤的事件。我们将继续尽最大努力监测岛上的物种，并让科学继续下去，但我们目前不确定全面的影响。”

;

;鸟岛被认为是地球上的< a href="https://www.bas.ac.uk/polar-operations/sites-and-facilities/facility/bird-island/">;最丰富的野生动物保护区;，也是许多濒临灭绝的鸟类的家园包括 50,000 对繁殖企鹅和 65,000 对海狗。该岛位于南乔治亚岛西北端附近，距福克兰群岛东南约 600 英里。

;
;

;;相关：;;野生鸟类获得对禽类的免疫力流感在致命的爆发中呈现出“令人鼓舞的迹象”;

;
;

;A ;关于禽流感影响南极洲的风险评估;海豹、海狮、贼鸥和海鸥面临的风险最大，其次是企鹅、猛禽、鞘嘴鸟和巨型海燕。

;

;梅根·杜瓦 (Meagan Dewar) 博士是南极野生动物健康网络的主席，也是该报告的主要作者表示，这种疾病可能会导致该地区“灾难性的繁殖失败”，“对许多野生动物物种造成毁灭性影响”。

;

;报告指出，“持续的疾病监测计划应该”。

;

;在野鸟迁徙路线的推动下，H5N1 在三个月内沿着南美洲传播了近 4,000 英里。研究人员表示，它已经传播到南美洲，因此很可能在某个时候到达南乔治亚岛。

;

;由于鸟岛上的阳性检测结果，大多数涉及动物处理的现场工作已被暂停。工作人员必须格外警惕，确保他们拥有干净的衣服和现场设备。

;

;该消息是在最近的研究显示英国（首次报告疫情爆发的地方）的一些海鸟开始开始;显示免疫力< /a>; 到 H5N1。

;;澳大利亚和以色列国旗
;

;过去六年澳大利亚已批准向以色列出口 322 项国防产品，根据周三参议院听证会上将引发质疑的新数据。

;

;政府编制的数据包括去年向以色列出口的 49 份许可证和今年前三个月的 23 份许可证，可能涵盖军事专用商品和军民两用设备。

;

;绿党国防发言人 David Shoebridge 表示，澳大利亚拥有“世界上最秘密、最不负责任的武器出口系统之一”，鉴于它不会分解导出的确切项目。

;
;

;;相关：;;Dfat 敦促以色列采取更强有力的定居点立场，联盟声称是“派系老板”在幕后黑手< /a>;

;
;

;舒布里奇将于周三在堪培拉举行的参议院估计听证会上向国防部询问出口情况，他表示，他“对澳大利亚材料被用于对加沙的袭击”。

;

;但是，这些数字并未涉及到如此详细的信息。在回答有关 Shoebridge 通知的问题时，政府透露，自 2017 年 1 月 1 日以来，已向以色列发放了 322 份军用或两用出口许可证。

;

;以色列的许可证数量在 2017 年达到峰值 62 份。 2021 年，该数字将下降至 49 个，随后在今年 1 月至 3 月进一步下降至 23 个。

;

;以色列是 Shoebridge 寻求国防出口数据的 14 个国家之一。菲律宾是问题国家中的第二大目的地，同期发放了 158 个许可证。

;

;其他目的地包括马里（70 个许可证）和布基纳法索（56 个许可证）。< /p>;

;;之前披露的信息表明;，澳大利亚在 2022 年 1 月 1 日至 11 月 9 日期间批准了 21 份向沙特阿拉伯出口军事或两用设备的许可证，比之前向该国出口的数量有所增加。

;

;在详细说明数字的答复中，政府表示“具有合法民用和商业用途的软件、无线电或化学品等广泛的商品和技术都需要许可证”。

;

;“每项出口许可证政府的回应称，该决定必须评估任何相关的人权风险以及澳大利亚遵守其国际义务的情况。

;

;“如果国防部发现出口产品可能用于促进侵犯人权，则将拒绝颁发许可证。 ”

;

;政府表示，每项出口申请都会根据外交政策、人权、国家安全、地区安全以及《武器贸易条约》等澳大利亚国际义务等标准进行评估。

;

;但是绿党认为澳大利亚应该与其他国家一起公布“我们向谁出售武器、这些武器是什么以及它们的成本”。

;

;“去年澳大利亚更换政府时，人们希望它能扭转局面联盟推动澳大利亚成为全球十大军火商。”舒布里奇说道。

;

;“相反，阿尔巴尼亚政府加倍加大了对世界上一些最麻烦政权的军售力度。”

; < p>;上周，美国老牌州; 国防部官员辞职，以抗议向以色列出售武器，称他在政治军事事务局工作的 11 年中做出了许多“道德妥协”。

;

;乔什·保罗 (Josh Paul) 在;LinkedIn 上发布的一封信;，他承诺“长期保留该职位”只要我觉得我能做的好事可以抵消我可能造成的伤害”。

;
;

;;相关：;;澳大利亚议会联合谴责包括反犹太主义和伊斯兰恐惧症在内的仇恨言论;

;
;

;“我今天离开是因为我相信，在我们当前关于继续（实际上是扩大和加速）向以色列提供致命武器的进程中，我已经达到了终点保罗写道。

;

;美国 ;本周表示;在以色列军队预计对加沙发动地面攻击之前，将向以色列派遣军事顾问和防空系统。

;

;澳大利亚政府已在 10 月 7 日哈马斯袭击后，与美国一起确认以色列的自卫权，但也呼吁保护平民生命和人道主义援助进入加沙。

;

;以色列驻澳大利亚大使阿米尔·迈蒙 (Amir Maimon)，将于周三在堪培拉发表讲话，谈论战争。

; Tue, 24 Oct 2023 22:22:02 +0800 Earth’s ‘vital signs’ worse than at any time in human history, scientists warnhttps://www.theguardian.com/environment/2023/oct/24/earth-vital-signs-human-history-scientists-sustainable-future
;;2023-10-24T14:00:39Z;
;
;;夏威夷拉海纳的一座教堂和棕榈树被火焰吞没
;

;地球的“生命体征”一个国际科学家小组警告说，现在的情况比人类历史上任何时候都更严重，这意味着地球上的生命正处于危险之中。

;

;他们的报告发现，他们用来追踪的 35 个行星生命体征中有 20 个气候危机正处于历史最严重的时期。除了温室气体排放、全球气温和海平面上升之外，这些指标还包括人类和牲畜数量。

;

;许多气候记录在 2023 年被大幅打破，包括全球气温、海洋温度和研究人员说，南极海冰的范围。有记录以来每月地表温度最高的月份是 7 月，这可能是地球 10 万年来最热的一次。

;

;科学家们还强调了加拿大的一个非同寻常的野火季节，产生了前所未有的二氧化碳排放。这些排放总量达 10 亿吨 CO;2;，相当于世界第五大污染国日本的全年排放量。他们表示，大面积烧毁可能预示着新火灾机制的转折点。

;

;研究人员敦促全球经济转型，优先考虑人类福祉，并减少富人的过度消费和过度排放。他们表示，2019 年，排名前 10% 的排放国排放量占全球排放量的近 50%。

; ;

;美国俄勒冈州立大学 (OSU) 的克里斯托弗·沃尔夫 (Christopher Wolf) 博士、该报告的主要作者表示：“如果不采取行动解决根本问题，人类从地球上索取的东西超过了它可以安全给予的，我们正在走向自然和社会经济系统的潜在崩溃，以及一个难以忍受的高温和食物和淡水短缺的世界。

;

;“到 2100 年，多达 30 亿到 60 亿人可能会发现自己;处于地球宜居区域之外;，这意味着他们将面临酷热、食物供应有限和死亡率升高的情况。”

;

;同样来自俄勒冈州立大学的威廉·里普尔教授表示：“我们星球上的生命显然正受到围攻。统计趋势显示了与气候相关的变量和灾害的令人震惊的模式。我们还发现，就人类应对气候变化而言，进展甚微。

;

;“我们的目标是传达气候事实并提出政策建议。科学家和我们的机构有道德义务提醒人类任何潜在的生存威胁，并在采取行动时发挥领导作用。”

;

;分析，;发表在《生物科学》杂志上;，是 2019 年;这份报告;得到了 15,000 名科学家的认可。

;

;“几十年来，科学家们一直警告说，未来将出现由持续的人类活动造成的极端气候条件，”报告称。 “不幸的是，时间到了……我们正在将我们的行星系统推向危险的不稳定状态。”合著者、英国埃克塞特大学蒂姆·伦顿教授表示：“这些创纪录的极端情况是他们本身就令人震惊，而且他们也面临着;触发临界点;可能会造成不可逆转的损害并进一步加速气候变化。

;

;“我们防止一连串气候临界点的最大希望是识别并触发;我们社会和经济的积极转折点;，确保快速、公正地过渡到可持续的未来。”

;
;

;;相关：;;“破纪录的记录”：人类终于打破了气候吗？;

;
;

;科学家们表示：“我们对 2023 年极端天气事件的凶猛程度感到震惊，这些事件导致了令人深感痛苦的痛苦场景。我们害怕我们现在进入的未知领域。”

; ;

;报告强调了严重的;中国的洪水;和;印度;，极端;美国的热浪;和异常;强烈的地中海风暴;导致利比亚数千人死亡。

;

;报告称，截至9月中旬，全球平均气温已连续38天比前期高出1.5℃以上。工业水平，这是世界限制气候危机的长期目标。研究人员表示，直到今年，这样的日子还是很少见的。

;

;科学家建议的其他政策包括逐步取消;化石燃料补贴;、加强森林保护、富裕国家转向植物性饮食以及采用< a href="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2022/nov/11/what-is-the-fossil-fuel-non-proliferation-treaty">;终止新煤炭项目的国际条约;并逐步淘汰石油和天然气。

;

;“我们还呼吁通过自愿计划生育以及支持妇女和女童的教育和权利，以性别公正的方式稳定并逐步减少人口，从而降低生育率，”他们说。

;

;“大问题需要大解决方案。因此，我们必须转变对气候紧急情况的看法，从一个孤立的环境问题转变为一个系统性的生存威胁。尽管全球变暖具有毁灭性，但它仅代表我们所面临的不断升级且相互关联的环境危机的一个方面，例如生物多样性丧失、淡水短缺和流行病。”

;

;Glen Peters 博士，全球Carbon Project最近表示，初步估计;2023年全球CO;2;排放量将增长1%< /a>; 到另一条记录。全球排放量必须下降 45%，才有可能将供暖温度控制在 1.5 摄氏度以下。

;

;9 月份，对 ;使用九个行星边界的地球系统;得出的结论是，这个星球的生命维持系统已遭到严重破坏地球“远远超出了人类的安全操作空间”。地球边界是关键全球系统（例如气候、水和野生动物多样性）的极限，超出这个极限，它们维持地球健康的能力就会面临失败的危险。

; Tue, 24 Oct 2023 20:22:01 +0800 AI risk must be treated as seriously as climate crisis, says Google DeepMind chiefhttps://www.theguardian.com/technology/2023/oct/24/ai-risk-climate-crisis-google-deepmind-chief-demis-hassabis-regulation
;;2023-10-24T12:00:35Z;
;
;;Demis Hassabis transforming into pixelated data
;

;The world must treat the ;risks; from artificial intelligence as seriously as the climate crisis and cannot afford to delay its response, one of the technology's leading figures has warned.

;

;Speaking as the UK government prepares to host a summit on AI safety, Demis Hassabis said oversight of the industry could start with a body similar to the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC).

;

;Hassabis, the British chief executive of Google's AI unit, said the world must act immediately in tackling the technology's dangers, which included aiding the creation of bioweapons and the existential threat posed by super-intelligent systems.

;

;“We must take the risks of AI as seriously as other major global challenges, like climate change,” he said. “It took the international community too long to coordinate an effective global response to this, and we're living with the consequences of that now. We can't afford the same delay with AI.”

; ;

;Hassabis, whose unit created the revolutionary AlphaFold program that ;depicts protein structures;, said AI could be “one of the most important and beneficial technologies ever invented”.

;

;However, he told the Guardian a regime of oversight was needed and governments should take inspiration from international structures such as the IPCC.

;

;“I think we have to start with something like the IPCC, where it's a scientific and research agreement with reports, and then build up from there.”

;

;He added: “Then what I'd like to see eventually is an equivalent of a Cern for AI safety that does research into that – but internationally. And then maybe there's some kind of equivalent one day of the IAEA, which actually audits these things.”

;

;The International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) is a UN body that promotes the secure and peaceful use of nuclear technology in an effort to prevent proliferation of nuclear weapons, including via inspections.

;

;However, Hassabis said none of the regulatory analogies used for AI were “directly applicable” to the technology, though “valuable lessons” could be drawn from existing institutions.

;

;Last week Eric Schmidt, the former Google chief executive, and Mustafa Suleyman, the co-founder of DeepMind, called for the creation of an IPCC-style panel on AI. Although UK officials support such a move, it is thought they believe its creation should be carried out under the auspices of the UN.

;

;Hassabis said AI could bring “incredible opportunities” in fields such as medicine and science but acknowledged existential concerns around the technology. Those centre on the possible development of artificial general intelligence (AGI) – systems with human or above-human levels of intelligence that could evade human control.

;

;Hassabis was one of the signatories in May of an ;open letter; warning that the threat of extinction from AI should be considered a societal-scale risk on a par with pandemics and nuclear war.

;

;“We should be starting that thinking and that research now. I mean yesterday, really,” he said. “That's why I signed, and many people signed, that letter. It's because we wanted to give credibility to that being a reasonable thing to discuss.”

;

;Some tech industry insiders are concerned that AGI or “god-like” AI could be only a few years away from emerging – though there is also a view that fears about the existential threat ;are being overplayed;.

;

;Hassabis said the world was a long time away from AGI systems being developed but “we can see the path there, so we should be discussing it now”.

;

;He said current AI systems “aren't of risk but the next few generations may be when they have extra capabilities like planning and memory and other things … They will be phenomenal for good use cases but also they will have risks.”

;

;The summit on 1 and 2 November at Bletchley Park, the base for second world war codebreakers including Alan Turing, will focus on the threat of advanced AI systems helping to create bioweapons, carry out crippling cyber-attacks or evading human control. Hassabis will be one of the attenders, along with the chief executives of leading AI firms including OpenAI, the San Francisco-based developer of ChatGPT.

;

;Hassabis's unit has achieved significant breakthroughs in AI technology such as creating the AlphaGo AI program that defeated the ;world's best player at Go;, a Chinese board game, and the groundbreaking AlphaFold project that predicts how proteins fold into 3D shapes, a process that has paved the way for breakthroughs in a range of areas including tackling disease.

;

;Hassabis said he was optimistic about AI because of its potential to revolutionise fields such as medicine and science but a “middle way” needed to be found for managing the technology.

;

;AI has leapt up the political agenda after the public release last year of ChatGPT, a chatbot that became a sensation owing to its ability to produce highly plausible text responses to typed human prompts, from producing lengthy academic essays to recipes and job applications, and even helping people revoke parking tickets.

;

;AI image-generating tools such as Midjourney have also astonished observers by creating realistic images including a notorious “photograph” of the pope in a puffer jacket, giving rise to concerns that rogue actors ;could use AI tools to mass produce disinformation;.

;

;Those fears have fed concerns about the ;potential power of the next generation of AI models;. Hassabis, whose unit is working on a new AI model called Genesis that will generate image and text, said he envisaged a Kitemark-style system for models emerging.

;

;This year the UK government launched the Frontier AI taskforce, which aims to create guidelines for testing cutting-edge AI models and could become a benchmark for international-level testing efforts.

;

;Hassabis said: “I can imagine in future you'd have this battery of 1,000 tests, or 10,000 tests could be, and then you get safety Kitemark from that.”

; Tue, 24 Oct 2023 20:22:01 +0800 Trial of Uyghur film-maker to begin in China this weekhttps://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2023/oct/24/trial-of-uyghur-film-maker-to-begin-in-china-this-week
;;2023-10-24T10:55:44Z;
;
;;Ikram Nurmehmet is under arrest in China.
;

;A Uyghur film-maker who was arrested in Beijing earlier this year will appear on trial in Xinjiang on Wednesday.

;

;Ikram Nurmehmet, 32, was taken from his home by Chinese authorities on 29 May and flown to Ürümqi, Xinjiang's capital, where he is being held in pre-trial detention on unknown charges, according to his supporters.

;

;Born and raised in Ürümqi, Nurmehmet is an independent film-maker based in Beijing, where he lives with his wife and infant son.
;
; Hours after his arrest, police called his wife to notify her of his transfer to Xinjiang and asked her to bring clothes for him to the airport. There, she was able to meet Nurmehmet briefly, in the company of three officers who handed her his wedding ring and amulet. He told her she, “must now do the best she can”, a source close to the family told the Guardian.

;

;Nurmehmet's mother, who lives in Ürümqi, filmed his arrival at the airport in Xinjiang. When she questioned the officers with him, she was told her son was “under investigation”.

;

;Known for portraying Uyghur protagonists in his work, Nurmehmet has directed many short films, some of which have been selected by film festivals in China and abroad. One film, ;Elephant in the Car,; tells the story of a Han Chinese woman sharing a taxi with two Uyghurs.

;

;“His work always focuses on Uyghur people's real lives, not in a propaganda way,” a source close to Nurmehmet said by phone over an encrypted messaging app. “He's one of the young Uyghur directors who engages with Chinese society the most, but unfortunately in the end it [led] him being arrested. He's very responsible for his family. He has a boy who [for] six months has not seen his father.”

;

;A month before his arrest, Nurmehmet had received a call from Xinjiang authorities requesting his return to Ürümqi to investigate the loss of his identity card. He refused and hung up. Later, his mother told him a childhood Uyghur friend he had once hosted while studying in Turkey had allegedly been detained, and warned that Nurmehmet might be under suspicion by association.

;
;

;;Related: ;;'Virtually entire' fashion industry complicit in Uighur forced labour, say rights groups;

;
;

;Before moving to Beijing, Nurmehmet had spent six years studying film-making at the Marmara University in Istanbul.

;

;Maya Wang, the associate director in the Asia division at Human Rights Watch, said Uyghurs with any connections to Islam, central Asia or the Middle East were automatically under suspicion of terrorism from Chinese authorities. Many were rounded up during a campaign of “collective punishment” and imprisoned arbitrarily without trial.

;

;“People who have these remote connections are considered terrorists or extremists or having ;ideological viruses;,” Wang said. “Many are still held in prison for having visited Turkey, or having attended (Islamic) funerals … Often, you hear of people dying in these facilities.”

;

;The Chinese state launched its “Strike Hard” anti-terrorism campaign in Xinjiang in 2014, after several terrorist attacks reportedly orchestrated by Uyghur separatists. Since then, an estimated ;half a million; people are believed to have been imprisoned during a crackdown that escalated in 2017. Among those with known prison terms, the average time of imprisonment is ;12.5 years;, according to Human Rights Watch.

;

;“There's less international attention now because the Chinese say they have closed the [detention] camps,” Wang said. “[But] the camps are part of a bigger, multifaceted campaign against Uyghurs, including the use of long prison sentences. Uyghurs continue to live in a state of fear.”

;

;Nurmehmet had previously been identified on a list of terrorism suspects known as the “Shanghai List”, which was obtained in 2020 by Australian hackers who looked through more than 1m surveillance records from the Shanghai Public Security Bureau.

;

;Last month, a leading Uyghur professor, Rahile Dawut, was reportedly ;sentenced to life in prison; for “endangering state security”. A specialist in Uyghur folklore and traditions, she was reported missing six years ago.

;

;A spokesperson for the Chinese embassy in London said: “We are not aware of the specifics that you mentioned. China is advancing law-based governance on all fronts and will continue to uphold the rule of law, conduct law enforcement and protect lawful rights and interests of individuals or organisations in accordance with the law.”

; Tue, 24 Oct 2023 19:22:01 +0800 Sudanese evacuees in the UK fear limbo as six-month visas begin to expirehttps://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2023/oct/24/sudanese-evacuees-in-the-uk-fear-limbo-as-six-month-visas-begin-to-expire
;;2023-10-24T10:46:19Z;
;
;;British nationals climb on to an RAF aircraft at Wadi Seidna airbase in Khartoum, Sudan, as part of the evacuation in April following the country's descent into civil war.
;

;People who were evacuated to the UK from war-torn Sudan fear they will be left in limbo when their six-month visas begin to expire this week. Evacuees, who have been living in hotels or with family members since April, say they have received no information from the Home Office about their future status.

;

;“I'm worried that on 26 October I finish the six months and if nothing happens with my visa and there's no extension I'll become an illegal immigrant,” said Azza Ahmed, who was a university lecturer in the capital, Khartoum, and is now living in a hotel in London with her son.

;

;The ;UK evacuated; 2,450 British and other nationals from Sudan between 25 April and 3 May after fighting broke out between the Sudanese armed forces and the Rapid Support Forces paramilitary over plans to transition to civilian rule. Up to 9,000 people have been killed in the violence and ;nearly 5.7 million displaced;. The UN says 25 million people are in need of humanitarian aid. Martin Griffiths, the UN emergency relief coordinator, said Sudan had been plunged into ;“one of the worst humanitarian nightmares in recent history”;.

;

;New arrivals were given leave to remain in the UK for six months ;outside the normal immigration rules; on compelling compassionate grounds.

;

;Azza Karrar, an assistant professor at the University of Khartoum, said when she arrived at Stansted airport, she was told that the government had yet to decide what would happen to evacuees after six months. She said she had still not been informed.

;

;“I literally have no place to go. My mother and father are in Egypt, but they have now refused to let any Sudanese nationals in,” said Karrar, whose husband is a British citizen. “It makes you feel like maybe you're not important. They've done schemes to help people before. Why not us?”

;

;The family, including three children, are living in a hotel in Preston, Lancashire.

;

;Katherine Soroya, a supervising immigration caseworker at the law firm Turpin Miller, said the evacuees she is working with were not informed of their status when they arrived in the UK, how they could extend their stay, or what benefits they were entitled to apply for under the visa.

; ;

;“Families in this position haven't got a clear explanation of what they're entitled to. It's pretty much been trial and error and lots of people trying different things with not much input from the Home Office,” said Soroya. “It's completely on those people to try and navigate a completely unnavigable system.”

;

;A Home Office spokesperson said evacuees could apply to extend their visas but Soroya said they have not directly been told this, nor were they told that their visas were granted outside the normal rules – information they need to correctly make an application.

;

;Soroya said applying for a visa is a long, complicated process, especially as most evacuees would also have to apply for a fee waiver beforehand to avoid having to pay up to £3,000, which excludes lawyers' fees.

;

;Ahmed, whose ex-husband is British, said: “I'm so depressed, I feel like I've been treated as someone with no value. I've felt this from the very first moment – the first time I went to the council and they didn't want to deal with me. I don't understand, the government brought me [here] and now they don't want to do anything to support me. Why bring us if you weren't happy for us to come here?”

;

;Waleed Abdallah, an immigration adviser at Devon and Cornwall Refugee Support, who is originally from Sudan, said the government should have an organised plan for Sudanese arrivals, as it has ;for Ukrainians; arriving in the UK.

;

;“If we put it in black and white, the Ukrainians were fleeing war, the Sudanese are fleeing war,” said Abdallah. “[But] they got visas before they left Ukraine and in the Sudanese case there's nothing like that. After they arrived, they [Ukrainians] got three-year visas, which is more settled than this case, where nobody knows what happens next.”

;

;He said there are limited options for the evacuees. Most people cannot apply for spousal visas or visas for family members left in Sudan because applicants require a regular income and secure accommodation to do so.

;

;A Home Office spokesperson said: “It is wrong to set these two sets of vulnerable groups [Ukrainian and Sudanese refugees] against each other. We have no plans to open a bespoke resettlement route for Sudan. Preventing a humanitarian emergency in Sudan is our focus right now and we are working with international partners and the United Nations to bring an end to fighting.”
;

; ;

;Selma Bedawi's story: 'The pressure comes from every side'
;

;

;The Travelodge overlooking one of London's busiest roads, surrounded by warehouses, is the fourth hotel Selma Bedawi has stayed in since she was evacuated from Sudan in April.

;

;From her two hotel rooms she battles on several fronts – for Ealing council to help her find housing, to find schools for her four children and to care for her 76-year-old mother, who suffers from several chronic illnesses.

;

;A British citizen, Bedawi was airlifted out of Sudan 10 days into the fighting that had blown out the windows of the family house. The British government promised help, but she says that since she arrived in the country, she has lived precariously, overcoming hurdles to find housing and food.

;

;“The pressure comes at me from every side, trying to deal with every problem,” she says. “What's the point of having a British passport if there's no advantage? The only thing they did for us was bring us on the planes.”

;

;The family is being hosted by Ealing council in west London because her brother lives in a studio flat in the borough, which is too small to house them all. Bedawi's husband and brothers, who are not British, remain in Sudan.

;

;Bedawi has no access to a kitchen, relying on a cooler box to keep cold the cheese she uses to make sandwiches. In a previous hotel in Slough, the manager threatened to evict her for using in her room a microwave that had been donated by a charity.

;

;She receives universal credit for four family members. Her eldest son and mother, Laila Bala, are ineligible. Bala's right to remain expires this week.

;

;Suffering from diabetes, hypertension and arthritis, Bala spends her day lying on her side, using a walker provided by a charity to get to the bathroom. “I lost everything, my home, my belongings, everything. The family is broken up everywhere. I'm so tired,” says Bala.

;

;Bedawi's 10-year-old twins are out of school. Her elder sons, 16 and 18, started college near Slough in September.

;

;“None of us know what will happen next,” says Bedawi. “It affects the children. One day they're happy, one day they're sad. It's not like them. They're asking more questions, trying to understand what's happening. They ask me if we're homeless.”

;

;An Ealing council spokesperson says: “Like most other London boroughs, we are struggling with a chronic shortage of housing and huge increases in the numbers of families needing emergency B&B accommodation as a result of the cost of living crisis. We always seek to support residents in need to the best of our ability, but the council is operating within a broken housing market and is under extreme pressure.”

; Tue, 24 Oct 2023 18:52:02 +0800 House Republicans to vote on which of eight speaker candidates to advancehttps://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2023/oct/24/house-speaker-vote-candidate-republican
;;2023-10-24T10:00:32Z;
;
;;A lawmaker tallies votes during Jim Jordan's failed bid to be the House speaker.
;

;House Republicans will hold an internal vote on Tuesday to determine which – if any – of their eight declared speaker candidates can win enough support to capture the gavel.

;

;Ahead of the Tuesday vote, eight House Republicans ;have launched; speakership bids: Jack Bergman of Michigan, Byron Donalds of Florida, Tom Emmer of Minnesota, Kevin Hern of Oklahoma, Mike Johnson of Louisiana, Gary Palmer of Alabama, Austin Scott of Georgia and Pete Sessions of Texas.

;

;One of the declared candidates, Dan Meuser of Pennsylvania, announced Monday evening that he would drop out of the race to instead focus on his “commitment to President Trump to help lead his campaign in Pennsylvania”.

;

;“I believe the House will elect a new speaker, and I know we will be in good hands with one of our colleagues running,” Meuser said in a statement.

;
;

;;Related: ;;Who are the Republican candidates for House of Representatives speaker?;

;
;

;The conference meeting, scheduled to start at 9am on Tuesday, comes four days after Jim Jordan of Ohio ;abandoned; his speakership bid due to entrenched opposition among more moderate Republicans.

;

;The House has now been without a speaker for three weeks, since the historic removal of the Republican Kevin McCarthy of California earlier this month. Because of Republicans' razor-thin majority in the House, any speaker candidate can only afford four defections within the party and still secure the 217 votes needed to win the gavel.

;

;As the House remains at a standstill, the chamber is unable to advance any legislation. Joe Biden ;has called; on Congress to pass a supplemental funding package providing aid to Ukraine and Israel, but the House cannot consider such a bill until a new speaker is elected.

;

;Despite the high stakes, House Republicans have been unable to unify around a single candidate. Following McCarthy's removal, the House majority leader, Steve Scalise of Louisiana, won the conference's speaker nomination, but he dropped out days later amid fierce backlash from hard-right lawmakers. Jordan then won Republicans' speaker nomination, but he was forced to withdraw after ;three failed floor votes;.

;

;The protracted standoff has inspired several House Republicans to throw their hats into the ring, and the conference must now whittle the list of eight declared candidates down to a single nominee.

;

;On Monday evening, the conference held a candidate forum to hear from each of the candidates, and the acting speaker, Patrick McHenry of North Carolina, has said Republicans may move to a floor vote “as soon as Tuesday”.

;

;Of the declared candidates, Emmer is arguably the best known within the conference, because of his position as the House majority whip. But Emmer has shown an occasional willingness to clash with Donald Trump, which could endanger his prospects of winning the speaker nomination. For example, Emmer is one of just two speaker candidates, along with Scott, who voted to certify the results of the 2020 presidential election despite Trump's false claims of widespread fraud in battleground states. However, Emmer also signed an amicus brief urging the US supreme court to invalidate the election results of four key swing states, which would have voided Biden's victory in the presidential race.

;

;In a potentially grim sign for Republicans' hopes of quickly reaching a resolution to the deadlock, the hard-right House Freedom Caucus has demanded that members remain in Washington DC until a new speaker is elected, jeopardizing the chamber's planned recess starting next week.

;

;“We must proceed with all possible speed and determination,” the caucus said in ;a statement; released on Monday. “Intentional and unnecessary delays must end. It serves only the lobbyists of the swamp and defenders of the status quo to continue to drag out this process.”
